PULL BACK TO REVEAL: MEDIUM SHOT —- RICHARD TUPELO (R.T.) - DAY RICHARD TUPELO is now a handsome 29-year old teacher in b blazer and polo shirt - with the same mischievous swagger and those same style glasses as when he was 9. My name is Richard Tupelo, and today you're going to forget everything you ever thought you knew ---

REVEAL: no he's not teaching at Harvard, or at some small liberal arts haven - he's in the worst high school in the Bronx: slackers, wannabe gangsters, a smattering of tough Albanian immigrants ... and those are the good kids. This is not honorable volunteer work. Richard Tupelo does not to be here. While Soljak might be the working class guy w made good, Tupelo is the rich kid whose life derailed. TUPELO (CONT’D) Since I'm just subbing today, and none of you will ever see me again, let's all maybe try to have some fun. That train of old rusted subway cars passes from darkness into daylight. EXT. BROOKLYN TRAIN YARD —- DAY The old train moves through acres of shiny new subway tra being readied for their runs.

The old train continues onto a barge waiting at the pier, joining dozens of other old subway cars already packed on the barge - and chained together. Perhaps these venerable cars are heading for use in some other town.

I don't understand.

This wall is not really hard, it's made up of trillions of floating atoms - and it's not "hard" until I press against it - the atoms in my body repelled by the atoms in the wall and if I pressed against this wall forever, imagine that, for the history of time --- (keeps pushing) (MORE )

If I lived forever and kept pressing against this wall there is a possibil- ity - of a moment - when the atoms in the wall might suddenly randomly arrange themselves so I'd go through the wall. Could happen right now. Or in a million years. Might never happen. But it could happen.
Like - you could walk through a wall?
Yeah. But something really, really different would have to be happening at just that moment in the universe to set up those circumstances.
If you went through the wall would you be on the other side of the wall, or inside the wall?
Good question. Why aren't you in some brainiac school instead of this dung-heap? - and I'm not joking. Don't like to study?
Life is tough.
Well, kid, the second thing you need to learn is: as tough as you think your life is, for someone else it's even worse.
(ignores that) If you went through the wall, what would it look like?

All I know is this: when we leave this room, pull down the blinds, close the door, this classroom will not look like this classroom. begin to imagine and that's what this room really looks like until someone opens the door and looks in - and in that instant the human eye and the human brain will turn this swirling cloud of electrons-molecules-atoms into what we think of as "real." We’ve combed every inch of track in the city --- (hates to admit:) Yes. It’s gone.
Tupelo’s eyes focus on the ominously-glowing subway map, the Power Spot in Brooklyn where all the lines converge.

Then every train is in danger now. And the one that’s missing --- if you want it back then get down here. Alone. No cops. Got that? Get down here. And I'll find it. Tupelo disconnects. To Jamal: TUPELO (CONT’D) Take her to Brooklyn Hospital. Go up to the fifth floor, find Nurse Judy, and tell them Tinkerbell is Renee’s niece.
Who’s Renee?
My wife. She’s a nurse there and they’1l do anything for her. (to Tinkerbell) She was the lady on the train.
Do I have to be her niece? Can I be her kid? Can she be my mother?
She’s not ready for that.
What are you gonna do?
Force that train back to where it escaped from, even if I have to shut down the whole city.  77.
They won’t let you do that.
They'll have to. Now get her to the doctor, get out of here! Jamal pulls Tupelo aside, concerned, whispers:

If the cops grab Tink’ --- gimme your phone number. Tupelo scribbles the number --- pushes Jamal to go. Jamal Tinkerbell head towards the secret exit. Tupelo glances o more at the map and its jumble of knotted lines in Brookl

Wait! Tinker--- “Teena” - right? -- - all those little papers you cut up and write on --- you got a piece of paper for me? She nods, finds in her pocket a sheet of paper. TUPELO (CONT’D) And a scissors.
Scissors? No - I got this --- A razor.
Fine. And some tape. And a pen!
You gonna get your train back with a razor blade, paper and a pen? Tinerbell has tape and a marker. Tupelo kisses her forehe
Good kid. Both of you. Now get to the hospital. Move! Jamal won't move:
How'd you know I'd say “carrot”?  78.
It was just a trick. Dumb trick. Get going.
But how’d you do it? You said you'd tell me.

(exasperated, but has to tell him: ) Ask anyone a series of fast simple questions - 2+8, 3+7, 5+5, 6+4 - that stops their thinking - then ask them to name a vegetable. Most people will say “carrot.” It’s a fact. Now get out of here. Go!
A TV NEWS REPORTER giving her LIVE REPORT stands in front crowds, cops, and Bomb Squad vans.

A child’s backpack on the tracks was all it took to shut down the subway at rush hour. But in today’s world most would agree it’s better to be safe than sorry. The good news: all subway lines are again in operation. Still, with the system just getting back underway, expect delays that will inconvenience millions of New Yorkers for several more hours. Better cancel those dinner plans - everyone is going to be late!

leaving Transit Authority HQ in a car driven by Terrell, instantly stuck in traffic between buses, news vans, and sea of pedestrians. IN THE CAR: Soljak looks out at his world in collapse. Terrell feeds Soljak even more problem
She keeps calling: she’s with the mayor and she’s looking for you and she’s really pissed.
Damn this traffic! Do something! Soljak, frustrated, bolts OUT OF THE CAR.  79.
No Chief. Don’t. Don’t leave me! Soljak hurries to a subway entrance - but someone grabs h

Answer your phone when I call you! The mayor will be at this new City Hall Station of yours in 20 minutes. Be there to meet him: 6 p.m. He will speak to the press about im- proved safety - the shuttle will be his example. There will be no discussion of missing trains. Under- stand? And put on a clean shirt. And I assume you found that train?
I’m on my way to get it right now. Soljak dashes down into the subway.

Soljak has commandeered a specialized, hot-yellow, eight- Vacuum Car - a futuristic-looking machine that cleans the tracks of the subway and the only thing now running on th new shuttle line. (to the Vac-Car operator) Anything special to running it? The OPERATOR - it’s a woman - shrugs: not really.
Wanna let me try? I used to do this. And today might be my last day down here.

(knows she shouldn't, but) Take the controls. The operator slides out of her seat and lets Soljak take - Soljak like a kid with a new set of toy trains. He give the Vac-Car some power - it hums down the track.
Yeah. Nothing special - just the best job in the world.  80.

Tupelo sits on a shiny plastic bench cutting a 2-inch wid 10-inch long strip of paper. A RUMBLE from far down the tunnel. He tenses - a powerful beam of light washes the station. And then it arrives, the strangest looking machi he’s ever seen. Soljak steps out onto the platform, the Vacuum-Car continues on. Soljak appraises Tupelo ---
Substitute teacher. Magician. And now: cutting paper dolls. (can’t believe this) I’m in your hands.
You ever hear of a Moebius Strip? Soljak squints. Tupelo shows him the strip of paper. Soun like a magician:

Two sides, right? If I make it into a loop I have an outside and an inside. But, if instead of attaching the ends as a loop I put a twist in the strip, and then attach the ends, what we’ve got is what’s called --- He twists the strip of paper and attaches the opposite en seals them with the tape --- TUPELO (CONT’D) A Moebius Strip --- Looks like a twisted figure eight.
Yeah --- and?

Now, if I take this marker and draw a line down the middle of the strip, look what happens --- Tupelo draws a line down the length of the twisted paper coil; as he follows the architecture of the coil the line  81. comes back to where it started having inscribed both side of the strip. Soljak takes Sokjak grabs TUPELO (CONT’D) I never lifted the pen. So, we had a strip of paper with two sides that now has only one side. Right? So what happened to the other side? Don’t guess. As simple as it seems, this is a profound mystery. You see, when any system makes more and more connections to other parts of itself the connectivity of that system increases in an exponential fashion - in the case of the subway forming a knot of staggering proportions. the seemingly simple moebius from Tupelo.
There were two sides. Now there’s one side. I'll play: where’s the other side?
Inside. I know that’s hard to imagine. And by “inside” I also mean “outside.”
“inside, outside” - I don’t have time for bullshit now --- (crunches the moebius) That train went missing and my system fell apart. Where’s my train? - and I want a nuts-and-bolts answer.
I’m afraid there’s only one answer: your train, with my wife, has slip- ped into a parallel dimension. Tupelo and slams him against the wall.
A para---!!? That’s why you brought me here!? Are you---!? You motherf---!
(cool as ice) Used to be just theory for me, but now I know it’s real.  82.
What's real!?

The world unseen. SOUNDS GRUMBLE, PILLARS RATTLE - a steady throb of tensio TUPELO (CONT’D) It was something I tried to convince myself of, it helped me imagine the work I was doing, helped me imagine that my kid ---, I tried to convince my wife of it, that there was a world of beauty and amazement right beyond our reach, but that only screwed things up more. But now --- (drags Soljak to ---) Look at your map, your subway is a 842 mile knot of amazing topological complexity, but now adding the shuttle line makes it even more complex - and the situation is now of an order so high that I suspect the connectivity - the properties of all the connections in the New York Subway System - has now become infinite. Can you imagine the properties of an infinite network? (off Soljak’s look) I can’t either. But the train is no longer in the realm of “where,” the whole System is now without a real “whereness,” and your new shuttle has caused the #3 train from Brook- lyn to jump into another dimension.
Fuck You.

You wouldn’t be here unless you knew something was wrong - something way wrong that you can’t explain. Well guess what: that kid who grabbed onto the back of that train - she actually saw it disappear. Now look at this --- Tupelo starts cutting length-wise through the crunched-by Soljak-but-not-broken moebius strip:  83. TUPELO (CONT’D) Now it really gets weird, watch: when I cut this again --- As he makes the final cut ---

The Moebius strip suddenly snaps itself into two separate moebius strips tied together in a knot! Huh? Soljak react So do we. (NOTE: this actually happens) TUPELO (CONT’D) C’mere, you need to see this --- Tupelo holds the “Moebius Knot” up against THE WALL-SIZED
THE MOEBIUS KNOT ---— --- IS A PERFECT MATCH WITH THE “POWER SPOT” JUMBLE OF SU
What the hell ---!???
Yeah: “what the hell.” What time did you connect the shuttle tracks to the rest of the system?
You know what time I connected it.

When you connected the shuttle tracks this morning you created this. Now I know this map is only an approximation of the system, but the actual connect- ions are even more complex. I got off at Bergen Street. The train continued but never made it to its next stop, but it did enter this newly created moebius knot and moved into a non- spatial plane. It continues to draw power from the System - you know that - so it’s got to be somewhere --- but it’s somewhere we can’t see. Soljak seems ready to punch Tupelo. Tupelo stands his gro  84. TUPELO (CONT’D) Six hundred years ago people weren’t morons - look what they built, the art they created, the cities - all these genius people - and yet for them the world was flat, and the earth was the center of the universe --- (pure energy) ---and then, suddenly, they were totally mind-fucked - suddenly the world was round - round! - and we weren’t the center of existence but one little speck at the edge of space - and then, when the microscope was invented, whoa! - suddenly there’s a whole other world --- of tiny little creatures - living inside our bodies! And so, imagine the future, people in touch with sounds and ideas, waves and currents and signals we can’t fathom - yet. ‘Cause reality itself doesn’t change but the reality in our minds always changes. So what the future will know, it won’t be just this. So are there other dimensions surrounding us, dimensions of time and space that fill in the gaps we can’t explain? Yes. I believe that. Yes.
It can’t be. I gave my life to this machine. Nuts and bolts. “For every action there’s a reaction.” That’s how the world works. Not---.
Then why are you here? Soljak tries to make the words to answer. Can’t. Tupelo moves in close:
What is it? I see it in your eyes. You know something. One long moment. Soljak turns away --- mutters. TUPELO (CONT’D) I didn’t hear you. What did you say?  85. Almost a whisper:
That blackened track, missing train --- (beat) It's happened before.
(now he grabs Soljak) What!? It’s happened before!???
Maybe a year ago, three in the morning, for a few seconds.

text: We were testing the current in the shuttle tunnel, no tracks yet, just the power grid, when an F-Train going through Rutgers Tunnel - it’s marker light goes off, then the light comes back on. So who cares, right? Couple a seconds. Coulda been a short circuit. But when the motorman pulls in he says some crazy shit happened - blames the conductor - conductor also says something weird happened - says the motorman must have blacked out at the con- trols - so now they start throwing punches at each other so we follow up: train’s fine, the signals are fine, but the track turned black where that train went off the board. But no one wants to get written up and it’s four in the morning - train was full of drunks, so nobody thinks about this shit - they just want to get home. But I think about it. Then I forget about it. Until now. Tupelo is astonished, elated - and terrified. His theory: true. Soljak: more frightened, more confused.
But why then, if the tracks did this ---  86.
Simple terms: trigger a nuclear reaction, before you get to criti- cal mass you get smaller reactions - that’s why that circuit test you ran only caused that blip, but now, with the tracks ---
Then how come every train in the system hasn’t --- how come there aren’t 10, 20, 100 trains missing?
There must be an exclusion princi- ple operating, such that only one train at a time can occupy the non-spatial network and --- Soljak’s heard enough, gets out his phone, starts a call
I’m getting a railer team down here, we’ll disconnect a stretch of track, that’1l break your Moebius thing and - POOF! --- we'll get that train back.
(grabs the phone away) No! No! You can’t do that!
What!? Why not?
The relevant non-spatial property is derived from the shuttle line, but now it belongs to the whole System!
In English!

If anything changes now, we'll lose that train forever. If you cut the knot --- Tupelo tears one piece of his paper moebius --- and the k  87. instantly collapses into two separate tangled strands. TUPELO (CONT’D) ---you can’t put it back together. The System has to stay the same until we bring back that train! text: all shiny silver, empty, clean - and real - glides throug the station. Tupelo has never seen a subway train like th Like a mirage. But it’s real. From Soljak: a sad laugh.
My life’s work.
It’s running already?
Special train.
To where?
City Hall. I’m supposed to be there - they were giving me a medal, front page news, a nice party.
You should be there: friends, family.
This is my family. There it goes. Soljak watches the train disappear into the darkness. Tup sees that Soljak’s cheeks are flushed, his eyes are red.
You gotta have someone.
I gave up on that a long time ago. (beat) Hope you got a plan.  88.

We need to propel that missing train back to where it escaped from and trap it--- (goes to the map) It’s living off the power from the rails, right? So by shutting down its power starting up here - moving from the Bronx down to Brooklyn, Queens to Brooklyn, pushing north from Coney Island, Bay Ridge and Rockaway - by cut- ting the power grid section-by- section we can chase it, corner it, and ---
That’s your plan? With the mayor back in town reassuring everyone that everything's perfectly normal?
We'll have to, and then we’1l direct all that energy into Bergen Street Station to shock our train back into the space we inhabit - it was shocked out, we’1ll need to shock it back in.
You want me to tell the mayor I’m shutting down New York “because a subway train’s in another dimen- sion”!? They’1l put me away.
But we have to do it.
(no good - final) Sorry, pal. No. Can’t. If that’s the only way, we’re both screwed.

Nurse Judy treats the cuts and lacerations on Tinkerbell’ hands, wrists, and knees. All around them children are cr - as if they have a special sense that something profound in the air. Jamal, watching Tinkerbell, concern. He holds Tupelo’s scribbled phone number, comments:  89.

Poor man. Lost a baby, now his old lady is gone --- poor Professor What-The-Hell’s-His-Name. He said he was gonna shut down the whole city to catch his train. They’re never gonna let him do that. Nurse Carla passes Jamal, growls at him:
How'd you know I'd say “carrot”? Nurse Judy is attending to Tinkerbell:
This is going to hurt --- Nurse Judy puts a wash of antiseptic on Tinkerbell palm -

Ouch. A SECOND NURSE gives Tinkerbell a tetanus shot --- TINKERBELL (CONT’D) Ouch! A THIRD NURSE plucks a steel splinter from Tinkerbell’s k Should be “ouch” --- but this time Tinkerbell does not re She just re-counts each hit of pain: TINKERBELL (CONT’D) One --- two --- three --- Suddenly she jumps to her feet: TINKERBELL (CONT’D) I know how to do it!

Tinkerbell grabs the number from Jamal, pushes aside nurs grabs a phone, calls - Tupelo answers. Tinkerbell screech TINKERBELL (CONT’D) You don’t have to shut down the whole city! I see it how - when there’s a fire in a tunnel the trains all keep running. They keep running ‘cause it’s three different powers down there!  90. Jamal holds back all the nurses:
Let her do her thing. They’re gonna put her in a genius museum.
Tupelo and Soljak listen to the breathless intensity pour out of the cell phone:
One’s the city electric. One’s all the signals and lights down there. And then there’s the train power! You can just shut down the tracks!
Is she right?
(realizes: ) Of course - split system, same since 1904 - every train pulls power from the third rail - DC current, s’got nothing to do with the city grid. (very impressed) Who you talking to?
jumping onto the nurses’ desk, yelling into the phone:
So if you cut the train power the stations would still be lit, the city’1l still be lit, but all the trains will stop! And then you can crash the system! Do it! Do it!
Somebody call Security!
Soljak to Tupelo racing up the escalator to the street.
How do we explain this to people?  gl.
We don’t. We can’t. We’ve got to bring it back, you and me, now. Before anything changes! We’ll do it, and no one on the street will even know it happened.
How long will it take?
30 - 45 - 60, tops. Trust me.
An hour? Even a half hour? You kidding? At rush hour?
Who said a half hour!? --- 30, 45 seconds! - we’re dealing with the speed of light!
ON TINKERBELL AND JAMAL --- rushing through the hospital lobby down into the subway entrance just outside the door
I do not want to miss this.
Tupelo and Soljak muscle through the rush hour crowd, Sol barking into his phone:
Morrissey! This is what I need from you ---
Morrissey (Soljak’s friend, the Jamaican dispatcher at th elevated tower in The Bronx), reacts:
You want me to do what? Aw, Soljak ---
Soljak is onto his next call ---  92.
It’s just a test. We’re running a test. Yes, it’s been approved.
Busiest station in the city. This dispatcher, a woman, crushes a cigarette pack.
Who orders a test at rush hour? Okay, Soljak, whatever you say.
Seagulls perch atop a lonely near-deserted modern tower i view of marshes and JFK Airport.
I’m not the only one, am I? At what time ---? 6:20? The dispatcher looks at his clock: now it’s 6:11.
Cave-like, loud, the deepest station in the system. This dispatcher holds his head as he takes the call from Solja
If it’s gotta be done it’s gotta be done.
They keep moving. Soljak keeps calling. Then, to Tupelo:
Say, when you were a kid did you ever take the subway?
All the time. Rode right up front. Looking out the window. Why?
What school you go to?
I went to private school. Why? Soljak puts a hand on Tupelo’s shoulder.  93.
Nothing. Just: “R-T,” you shoulda been nicer to the trains. Off Tupelo’s look, Soljak keeps rolling calls ---
In view of Nathan's, “The Cyclone” roller coaster and the beach. This elevated junction has multiple platforms bene a vaulted steel roof. A guy on the phone, SECOND IN COMMA does not comprehend:
I don’t know you or what you’re talking about but I’11 tell Bob.
Just tell Bob it’s Soljak, and tell him to cut power for two minutes at 6:20.
AN OLD BRICK BUILDING looks over the vast Maintenance Yar where subway cars return at the end of their runs to be washed, patched, and then sent out again.

A small woman, MS. JOHNSON, stands in front of a big pane with 86 levers, her hands in motion like an orchestra conductor, she walks back and forth operating the switche that pump trains into the system. Someone hands her a pho
(as she works the levers) Why Mister Soljak, how is that big party they got going for you today? They must have lost my invitation.
Soljak purrs into the phone for this call:
Why Ms. Johnson, so good to hear your voice. I have a tiny little favor to ask ---
The little woman stiffens:  94.
What are you drinking at that party? You want me to stop sending out trains?
Like bitter sugar:
Just for one little minute. And --- I’m missing the party too.
